displayed_text: Patient: Alright. Doctor: Back off a little. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Sit tight. You know who’s coming next. Patient: My buddy. Doctor: M___. Patient: Oh, M___. Doctor: Oh. Patient: My papers. I’m going to have paper to sign this way. Doctor: Of course. There’s always papers to sign. Patient: How long do you think before we actually start? Doctor: Uh, well it’s up to you but probably in a week or two. I wanna to get going. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: So they’ll approve it probably the next Thursday? Doctor: Correct. Exactly. And then they’ll say oh the note says you’re off study this is standard run of the mill dose of taxo… oh you want to give Neulasta on day two because you’re worried about having compromise of your white cells, which is still a little you know not at the most robust, but your cell lines have- Patient: Sure. Doctor: - gone down because of the previous chemo. But look we have a great respond, so let’s just move on boys and girls. Doctor: And the then they’ll go oh that makes sense Stan and then you show up and then there we are. Patient: Yeah, okay, okay. Doctor: So I think we should just reschedule for next Thursday, the shot on Friday and that’s that. Patient: Okay, okay. Reschedule what for next Thursday? Family Member: Chemo. Doctor: Chemo. Patient: Oh and then have that follow-up shot on Friday? Doctor: Correct.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which actually will be sort of . So if you feel comfortable continuing with the next step, the next step will be for me to get a Patient: Okay. Yeah I’m interested uh huh so if the next step is I’ll read this and I’ll talk to my wife and my children and I’ve basically tell them this is the route that I wanted to go as far as radiation. I mean you’ve given me enough information with the random selection- Doctor: Correct. Patient: so I understand. My biggest concern is around the randmon selection is how long I’ll remain in that before actually having… Doctor: Right, now one thing to say about that and this is true of every clinical trial, you have the option to if you don’t want to. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But we, the is if you drop out Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but every once in a while we make an exception , but in general the cavet is dropping out early is you Patient: And this therapy is part of the trial, it’s not just something that’s being done, it’s associated with this trial. It’s not and say this is what I want to do at this time. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: So, the first thing is to, uh, see if I can come up (healthy) Doctor: Yeah. Just to see, yeah, how much it’s gonna cost ya. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Patient: I think last time I was on the Xtandi, they wanted to know if I have any income to speak of or – Doctor: Yeah. They’ll do the wallet check and everything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If they think you make enough money that you should be able to pay for it, then they’re not gonna give you one of these, uh, uh, grants. Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Yeah. Okay. Family Member: Alright. Patient: With the Xtandi, the PSA still has to go up. Doctor: I’ll write that out for you what we’re lookin’ at. Okay? Patient: The ARV seven has to stay positive and, uh, (stuff)

Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Yes. Is this a? He can do a new activation code? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Sounds good. Other questions for me? Patient: No, I think I understand where we're going. Right now, we haven't any delineated factors that we have to charge in any direction so. Doctor: Good. So there are study options and then we have to do usual care then Patient: Right. Okay. Yeah sounds good. Doctor: You’ll get your orders to get your blood work, the Aximun scan maybe at our baby site, you know. Patient: Okay Doctor: So, we'll get into a radiology schedule- Patient: All right. Doctor: -uh as we need it, if I find more out by the end of the week, but how to get it scheduled. I’ll let you know.

Family Member: So all the other tests that he’s had- Doctor: Mm, hmm. Family Member: — the ultrasound, all that stuff, the x-ray, I mean everything’s good? Doctor: Okay, I mean good in the sense there’s nothing to do other than change the treatment and move on to the next level. Family Member: It hasn’t spread to anything else. Doctor: Nothing else. I mean it’s just bone. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Organs are good. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Okay, okay still got diabetes to worry about, not the cancer. Patient: So bone as in spine or is it now in Doctor: Yeah, spine as in spine and pelvis. So it’s right here. Healthcare Professional: So quit climbing ladders and falling.

Patient: Right. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So I think I cannot do a whole lot by the report, I do need to look at the actual scan which I will do right now. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ll tell you about both those things I’m hoping today before you leave. Patient: Before we leave. Doctor: So we make some decisions. Patient: Anything else? Family Member: No unless you want to ask her about… Patient: No. Doctor: What? Laughs]] Patient: Oh I got a little inflammation from the penis um well inversion you know and you’re gonna get urine up in there and it’s gonna get inflamed. I’ve been using my statin ointment and that helps somewhat, but uh…

Family Member: How is his reaction or side effects kind of differ from the way they are right now. Doctor: Well, that's, you know, for Xtandi, it's the potential tiredness, a little balance issues, none of which has plagued you, but chemo is more chemo usual chemo type of things, like hair thinning or hair loss. Family Member: We don’t worry about that. Doctor: You can get neuropathy, you know, over time, which is numbness and tingling. Patient: I can’t get more than I got. Doctor: Well, I'm hoping it's not that bad, you're stable, but you know, if it gets much worse you're not even eligible for the trial. The other parts are, you know, we watch the liver function, we check by blood test. Some people get a weird taste in their mouth, not necessarily metallic, but just doesn't taste right. Family Member: In other words, when he eats it’s not going to be as wonderful. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: One of the things you enjoy. Doctor: But you know, if that's bad and we stop it and quality of life's terrible anymore Family Member: Well, with this neuropathy would this be something that would prevent him from being on this trial. Doctor: Well, you know, it’s yes, in the sense- Family Member: He definitely has it?

Patient: That’s right. Doctor: But who knows what will get developed in the meantime. Patient: Exactly, okay, alright. Doctor: Good, yeah. Patient: Um, about how long do you think this will take for them to… Doctor: To get going? Patient: To get going? Doctor: A week or two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, it will take a week or two for you to meet up with him and then we’re off and running so soon. Patient: Okay and they do the scheduling? Doctor: Yeah then it’s all them.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I made a copy for you so you can, um, this, this has a pretty good amount of information. Family Member: We get to keep this? Doctor: Yeah. It’s yours – it’s all, it’s in our computer. Family Member: So, keep the appointments that we have already? Like the hormone shot in January. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: And, there’s something else? Patient: Is this in my chart? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I just printed it out. Family Member: Uh, yeah.

Family Member: It’s almost like a motivation machine. Doctor: Wow. Family Member: It doesn’t make him drowsy at all. Doctor: Now, does it uh cause you any problems, though? The Norco doesn’t constipate you? Patient: No. Doctor: Does it help with the pain? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up. Family Member: It went up. Yes. Doctor: From four to nine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay? Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Huh. Doctor: I still get my blood test. Patient: Oh okay you still uh? How many times? Doctor: Once a year now. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So in twenty years it’s probably gonna be time for me to stop, but we check your blood, we’ll be checking blood for a long time.
PAT So, so, so after um after September and you know everything keeps going… We’ll do it every six months. Patient: Every six months. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right. Patient: I thought it was, I thought it was longer than that, but okay. Doctor: And then once we get a few years out beyond that, once we get out to five years, then we’ll start making it every year.

Family Member: Oh. Sounds interesting. Doctor: It’s, it’s, you know, on one of those Zagat books and stuff. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It’s just, they do creative things. It’s not your standard mac and cheese. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: You like it? Family Member: Right. Doctor: So you’re not into it, but it, it just tastes really good. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then there’s the H___ C___, which is also pretty good. Family Member: I’ve heard of it. Okay. Doctor: Right across the street.

Family Member: Right, Okay. Doctor: -combination that you just outlined kind of again makes sense, but I view it as to me the main purpose of doing the radio therapy would not be necessarily that you will have some sort of combined benefit in conjunction with the hormone therapy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It would be for the purpose of delaying the hormones that much longer. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: So I kind of view that as the primary motivation for doing that. But to me the primary motivation for radiation would be we’re doing something rather than just continue to observe you. Patient: Right. Doctor: But that’s something may not be so as aggressive or as detrimental on your quality of life as the hormone therapy, for example, which has all these systemic side effects. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I wasn’t necessarily seeing it as hormones plus radiation at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I was seeing it as doing the radiation therapy as a way to sort of avoid or push back the need for the hormones.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine. Patient: There is? Doctor: There is. Yeah, yeah, there's one I think that's purple and I'm pretty sure there's a blue one. Again, I peruse the poop in the mouth aisle, because I don't like to recommend things that you can't get access to. You know, when it sounds good on paper and in the textbooks, and then you go to Meijer, you go to Rite Aid and you're like, “what are you talking about, I've never seen it”. So I will peruse the same store as you guys shop at because if I don't see it then how are you going to play it? So I do know Crest has one that says no alcohol that's a blue and I'm pretty sure Listerine is purple that's a no alcohol, so those are two really good ones. You know I’d still cut it a little bit with the water. Family Member 1: What about toothpaste? Doctor: Same with a lot of the whitening and all that is very harsh on the gums. You know there's Sensodyne, which is very calming. Family Member 1: I have to do a prescription because Doctor: Oh, okay.
